title: Dog the Bounty Hunter's Duane Chapman has ditched white foods after pulmonary embolism diagnosis
text:
Duane 'Dog' Chapman has revealed that he's eliminated white foods from his diet in a bid to improve his health, following a life threatening pulmonary embolism.

The 66-year-old Dog The Bounty Hunter star told TMZ that he's made some major adjustments to his diet since he was hospitalised with chest pains last month.

Speaking during an outing in New York City, Duane – who lost his wife Beth Chapman following a battle with cancer in June – said he's 'trying to get better' by ditching such processed foods as sugar, bread, pasta, and crackers from his diet.

Food for thought: Duane 'Dog' Chapman has revealed that he's eliminated white foods from his diet in a bid to improve his health, following a life threatening pulmonary embolism

Embracing a more natural diet, his food intake now includes more fresh vegetables and fish as he battles his way back to good health following his brief hospital stint.

During an appearance on The Dr. Oz Show last month, Duane revealed his diagnosis and shared how his attitude about death has changed since receiving it.

'I said, after Beth left, I'm not afraid to die... I take that back. I'm not afraid to [die], but I don't want to,' the TV personality told Dr. Mehmet Oz.

Recent widow: The Dog The Bounty Hunter star's wife, Beth Chapman, passed away in June after a lengthy battle with lung cancer at just 51 years old

A pulmonary embolism is a potentially life threatening condition where a blood clot travels to your lungs, blocking blood flow to them.

After receiving the diagnosis, the bounty hunter revealed on the show that he was overcome with the fear of death.

'Oh I was afraid to die. I said, "Please let go of my heart, honey. Quit squeezing my heart,"' he explained.

Diagnosis: During an episode of The Dr. Oz Show last month, Duane revealed his pulmonary embolism diagnosis and shared how his attitude about death has changed since receiving it

'You’re a ticking time bomb,' Dr. Mehmet Oz told him. 'You’re not going to be here with the heart the way it is right now. Fear of death is normal.

'I’m surprised you don’t fear death when you’re chasing after convicts. But when you run away from doctor, that means you have to do your own doctoring.'

Duane previously said he believed the chest pains were due to a 'broken heart' following his wife's passing.

The recent widower is 'weary of doctors and hospitals,' according to People, but he told the outlet he's not going to go out with out a fight and he's now on the road to recovery.

On death and dying: 'I said, after Beth left, I'm not afraid to die... I take that back. I'm not afraid to [die], but I don't want to,' the TV personality told Dr. Mehmet Oz

Dr. Oz, who went to visit Chapman at his Denver, Colorado, home, was also given a tour of the star's home, including a number of pictures and artworks of his late wife.

The Bounty hunter's wife, Beth Chapman, passed away in June after a lengthy battle with lung cancer. She was just 51 years old.

His co-star on their new reality series, Dog's Most Wanted, Beth Chapman was diagnosed with stage 2 throat cancer in September 2017, though it later went into remission.

The disease ultimately spread to her lungs, leading to a stage 4 diagnosis before she was placed into a medically-induced coma.
